Canine Coronavirus.description: A highly contagious viral disease affecting the intestines of dogs, causing diarrhea and vomiting.
Canine Coronavirus.treatment: Ensure hydration, provide a bland diet, and monitor symptoms. A vet visit is recommended if symptoms persist beyond 3 days.

Canine Distemper.description: A serious viral disease that affects the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and nervous systems of dogs. It is highly contagious and often fatal.
Canine Distemper.treatment: Requires immediate veterinary attention. Supportive care includes IV fluids, antibiotics for secondary infections, and seizure management if needed.

Canine Herpesvirus.description: A viral infection that primarily affects newborn puppies, causing respiratory distress and neurological symptoms. In adult dogs, it may remain latent or cause mild symptoms.
Canine Herpesvirus.treatment: Newborn puppies require warmth and supportive care. Infected adult dogs should be monitored for symptoms and isolated to prevent transmission.

Canine Influenza.description: A contagious respiratory infection in dogs, often causing coughing, nasal discharge, fever, and lethargy.
Canine Influenza.treatment: Most cases resolve with rest, hydration, and supportive care. Severe cases may require hospitalization for oxygen therapy and IV fluids.

Kennel Cough.description: A highly contagious respiratory infection that causes a persistent, dry, hacking cough. It spreads easily in areas with many dogs, such as kennels and dog parks.
Kennel Cough.treatment: Mild cases may resolve on their own with rest and hydration. Severe cases may require antibiotics or cough suppressants as prescribed by a vet.

Canine Parvovirus.description: A highly contagious and often fatal viral infection that attacks the gastrointestinal tract, causing severe vomiting, diarrhea, and dehydration.
Canine Parvovirus.treatment: Immediate veterinary care is required. Treatment includes IV fluids, anti-nausea medication, and intensive monitoring for secondary infections.

Rabies.description: A fatal viral disease that affects the nervous system, leading to behavioral changes, aggression, paralysis, and death. It is transmitted through bites from infected animals.
Rabies.treatment: There is no cure for rabies once symptoms appear. Prevention through vaccination is essential. Any suspected exposure requires immediate veterinary evaluation.

Canine Minute Virus.description: A parvovirus-related infection that primarily affects young puppies, causing vomiting, diarrhea, and sometimes heart complications.
Canine Minute Virus.treatment: Supportive care includes hydration, electrolyte therapy, and monitoring for secondary bacterial infections. Severe cases may require hospitalization.

Infectious Canine Hepatitis.description: A viral infection affecting the liver, kidneys, spleen, and lungs of dogs. Symptoms range from mild to life-threatening.
Infectious Canine Hepatitis.treatment: Supportive care with IV fluids, liver-protective medications, and monitoring of organ function is necessary. Severe cases may require hospitalization.

Pseudorabies.description: A viral disease that affects the central nervous system, leading to intense itching, seizures, and paralysis. It is often fatal in dogs.
Pseudorabies.treatment: There is no effective treatment for pseudorabies. Supportive care may help manage symptoms, but prevention through avoiding contact with infected animals is crucial.
